notes.text: Red Hat Ansible Tower 3.6.2-1 - RHEL7 Container
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
* Added a command to generate a new SECRET_KEY and rekey the database
* Removed the guest user from the optionally-configured RabbitMQ admin interface (CVE-2019-19340)
* Fixed slow queries for /api/v2/instances and /api/v2/instance_groups when smart inventories are used
* Fixed assorted issues with preserving permissions in the Ansible Tower backup playbook (CVE-2019-19341)
* Fixed a partial password disclosure when special characters existed in the RabbitMQ password (CVE-2019-19342)
* Fixed hang in error handling for source control checkouts
* Fixed an error on subsequent job runs that override the branch of a project on an instance that did not have a prior project checkout
* Fixed an issue where supervisord would not shut down correctly
* Fixed an issue where jobs launched in isolated or container groups would incorrectly timeout
* Fixed link to instance groups documentation in the user interface
* Fixed retrieval of Red Hat subscription data when running in OpenShift
* Fixed editing of inventory on Workflow templates
* Fixed multiple issues with OAuth2 token cleanup system jobs
* Fixed custom email notifications for workflow approve and deny
* Updated SAML implementation to automatically log if authorization exists
* Updated AngularJS to 1.7.9 for CVE-2019-10768
* Updated installer to not install PostgreSQL server on all nodes
* Updated bundled installer to contain both Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 and 8 builds
notes.title: Details

branches.name: Red Hat Ansible Tower 3.6 for RHEL 7

product.name: Red Hat Ansible Tower 3.6 for RHEL 7

full_product_name.name: ansible-tower-36/ansible-tower@sha256:dcaf6e0914afb8cecf1962fbc1d6afa5a132f85ea20f56e18102310ad11515b5_amd64 as a component of Red Hat Ansible Tower 3.6 for RHEL 7

acknowledgments.summary: This issue was discovered by Red Hat.

cwe.name: Initialization of a Resource with an Insecure Default

notes.text: A flaw was found in Ansible Tower 3.6.1 and 3.5.3 where enabling RabbitMQ manager by setting it with '-e rabbitmq_enable_manager=true' exposes the RabbitMQ management interface publicly, as expected. If the default admin user is still active, an attacker could guess the password and gain access to the system.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Tower: enabling RabbitMQ manager in the installer exposes the management interface publicly
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details: For information on upgrading Ansible Tower, reference the Ansible Tower Upgrade and Migration Guide: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible-tower/latest/html/upgrade-migration-guide/index.html

The issue could be mitigated by limiting the access of the interface to internal trusted networks, limiting the ports open and set the firewall with more restrictive rules. Some of these instructions are already suggested in the Ansible Tower documentation as part of the Ansible Tower Administration Guide. Issue could be also mitigated by deleting the guest default user by running the command "rabbitmqctl delete_user guest".

vulnerabilities.title: Tower: enabling RabbitMQ manager in the installer exposes the management interface publicly

acknowledgments.summary: This issue was discovered by Red Hat.

cwe.name: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource

notes.text: A flaw was found in Ansible Tower 3.6.1 and 3.5.3 where files in '/var/backup/tower' are left world-readable. These files include both the SECRET_KEY and the database backup. Any user with access to the Tower server, and knowledge of when a backup is run, could retrieve every credential stored in Tower. Access to data is the highest threat with this vulnerability.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Tower: intermediate files during Tower backup are world-readable
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Red Hat CloudForms 4.7 (5.10) release is not affected, because we do not run Ansible Tower backups from CloudForms.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.

vulnerabilities.title: Tower: intermediate files during Tower backup are world-readable

cwe.name: Generation of Error Message Containing Sensitive Information

notes.text: A flaw was found in Ansible Tower 3.6.1 and 3.5.3 when /websocket is requested and the password contains the '#' character. This request would cause a socket error in RabbitMQ when parsing the password and an HTTP error code 500 and partial password disclose will occur in plaintext. An attacker could easily guess some predictable passwords or brute force the password.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Tower: special characters in RabbitMQ passwords causes web socket 500 error
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details: For information on upgrading Ansible Tower, reference the Ansible Tower Upgrade and Migration Guide: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible-tower/latest/html/upgrade-migration-guide/index.html

This issue could be mitigated by setting or changing the RabbitMQ passwords without using the specials characters. Complex passwords could still remain or even increase by using unpredictable longer strings. This adds much more entropy rather than just using special characters in shorter strings.

vulnerabilities.title: Tower: special characters in RabbitMQ passwords causes web socket 500 error
